doc.title: Jefferies
doc.source_uri: 2025-08-29/Tackling The Key Debates Head OnTackling The Key Debates Head On_2025-08-29

passages.text: EUROPE | Food & HPC Nestle

We attended a CEO/CFO hosted self- side meeting this AM. NESN did a good (refreshing) job of proactively tackling the key focus areas for the investment case. We summarise the feedback on those 4 areas below. Our conclusion: progress continues at a steady pace. There were a lot of issues built the last few years, those will continue to take time to fully correct. 2H cons RIG looks low to us, but margin & FCF metrics will take longer to match more bullish hopes.

1/ Organic / RIG growth The co is confident that \(- 0.2\%\) RIG in 2Q marks a trough (VA cons \(3Q / 4Q = +0.4\% /0.5\%)\) . Market share momentum is building - gradually. It also expects improved elasticities as consumers & competitors adapt to coffee / cocoa costs in 2H & align with the price levels taken in 1H by NESN. There is a major innovation/activation program planed for October, facilitated by organisational and R&D approach changes YTD.

JEF: We think cons is too low for 2H25 RIG (JEF 1.2% v 0.4%), premised on an easier comps (ex China & VMS, see point 4) and improving competitiveness YTD. That beat would be useful for building credibility on the strategy working.

2/ Op margin FY25. It remains confident it can get to 'the bottom end of the \(16\% +\) guide. There is an insistence that growth focus will not waver in order to meet \(16.0\%\) . The A&P levels it claims are at least in line with the start of year plan, but benefitting from falling non- working media costs (dropping from c30% of A&P to \(20\%\) mid- term) and better returns than planned. 2H margin continues to be guided to c15.5% (- 130bp YoY). FY26 margin "should improve", with cost saves building & less commodity inflation aligned - with the full build- up on pricing & innovation plans.

JEF: We continue to think the margin reset was compromised. A bit more revolution (more extensive price resets & brand equity recovery) could have been more effective and/or a better rebase point for the investment case. FY25 margin still feels a risk to us, if the co does the "right things" in 4Q. But consensus now seems to be listening re. margin recovery (ie getting to \(17\% +\) ) is at best a long term journey & not a given.

3/ Cashflow & dividend, NESN reiterates a commitment to improving FCF & increasing dividend. FCF headwind in recent periods is put down to: over zealous capex spending on "overly optimistic second expectations", input cost inflation levels - notably coffee, tariff mitigation plans for inventory & the profitability reset. The target is for FCF over CHF8bn in FY 25 (vs 1H 2.3bn) De leverage is expected to be assisted by divestment plans.

JEF: We suggested a dividend cut was more "when not if", given the long term disconnect of a CHF cash commitment vs strength of that currency. But that was dismissed, with the importance of the dividend to many investors flagged. We estimate FCF pre dividend (CHF8.1bn) to be CHF7.9bn this year, with gearing c3x net debt/ EBITDA. The FCF we set does step up to CHF9bn next year, but cCHF1bn pa pay down on net debt of CHF55bn seems unnecessarily restrictive still we think.

4/ Growth dilution from China & VMS. The notable reset needed across these 2 operations is called out as a key dilution of group sales delivery. Covering \(12\%\) of sales, these units will face an even tougher RIG comp in 2H25 (1H24 RIG \(1\% v 8\%\) 2H24). That will weigh until 2026, but should be offset by the easier comps in the remaining \(88\%\) .

JEF: China and VMS are symptomatic of a wider group issue, too much 'push' and a fanciful hope of up to \(18.5\%\) op margin this year at one point. China & VMS are the clearest victims of that past, but we think it is similar elsewhere. That kind of mismanagement takes time to correct, but it is encouraging that correction should come - gradually.

\*Prior trading day's closing price unless otherwise noted.

With a market cap of c. \(\) 230bn, Nestle is the food company by market cap. Revenues were CHF 91bn in 2024. The company generates its revenues from a diverse mix of food and beverage products, with its two largest categories, pet food & coffee, contributing \(47\%\) of Group sales in 2024. Nestle owns around \(20\%\) of L'Oreal, which is reported as an associate and accounts for a high- DD share of total market cap. The US is Nestle's largest geographic market, accounting for \(35\%\) of sales in 2024. Greater China accounted for \(6\%\) of sales.

We value Nestle on the basis of 10Y discounted cash flow and EV/EBITDA based exit value, from which we add/subtract the value of its L'Oreal associate and minority stakes on a marked- to- market basis. We also subtract net debt/cash and any pension liabilities to derive a fair equity value. Risks to valuation include bond yields, FX, and commodities.
(Article 3(1)e and Article 7 of MAR) Recommendation Published Recommendation Distributed

Buy - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of \(15\%\) or more within a 12- month period. Hold - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of plus \(15\%\) or minus \(10\%\) within a 12- month period.

Underperform - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of minus \(10\%\) or less within a 12- month period. The expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) for Buy rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(\) 10\(is 20\%\) or more within a 12- month period as these companies are typically more volatile than the overall stock market. For Hold rated securities with an average security price consistently below\) \ \(10\) , the expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) is plus or minus \(20\%\) within a 12- month period. For Underperform rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(\) 10\(, the expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) is minus\) 20\% \(or less within a 12- month period.
NR - The investment rating and price target have been temporarily suspended. Such suspensions are in compliance with applicable regulations and/or Jefferies policies.
CS - Coverage Suspended. Jefferies has suspended coverage of this company.
NC - Not covered. Jefferies does not cover this company.

Restricted - Describes issuers where, in conjunction with Jefferies engagement in certain transactions, company policy or applicable securities regulations prohibit certain types of communications, including investment recommendations.
Monitor - Describes securities whose company fundamentals and financials are being monitored, and for which no financial projections or opinions on the investment merits of the company are provided.

Jefferies' methodology for assigning ratings may include the following: market capitalization, maturity, growth/value, volatility and expected total return over the next 12 months. The price targets are based on several methodologies, which may include, but are not restricted to, analyses of market risk, growth rate, revenue stream, discounted cash flow (DCF), EBITDA, EPS, cash flow (CF), free cash flow (FCF), EV/EBITDA, P/E, PE/growth, P/CF, P/FCF, premium (discount)/average group EV/EBITDA, premium (discount)/average group P/E, sum of the parts, net asset value, dividend returns, and return on equity (ROE) over the next 12 months.

Jefferies Franchise Picks include stock selections from among the best stock ideas from our equity analysts over a 12 month period. Stock selection is based on fundamental analysis and may take into account other factors such as analyst conviction, differentiated analysis, a favorable risk/reward ratio and investment themes that Jefferies analysts are recommending. Jefferies Franchise Picks will include only Buy rated stocks and the number can vary depending on analyst recommendations for inclusion. Stocks will be added as new opportunities arise and removed when the reason for inclusion changes, the stock has met its desired return, if it is no longer rated Buy and/or if it triggers a stop loss. Stocks having 120 day volatility in the bottom quartile of S&P stocks will continue to have a 15% stop loss, and the remainder will have a 20% stop. Franchise Picks are not intended to represent a recommended portfolio of stocks and is not sector based, but we may note where we believe a Pick falls within an investment style such as growth or value.
Nestle (NESN SW: CHF74.90, HOLD)
